                 stopped

reviews.review_text: This was my first Penelope Lively book and I loved it.

A solid piece of work about the pain of loss in WW II, the Egyptian campaign, and how it affects one's life. Brilliant and evocative, in style similar to The English Patient. Worth the time and effort of perusing a deeply personal narrative.
Excellent writing, however I found the lead character Claudia portrayed with a horrible personality.
The characters were so cold and unlikable, and they took themselves too seriously.
There are passages in this book that were so visceral and so outstanding that I highlighted them for future reference
Clever but main character is too narcisstic and unlikable me for me to care much about her past or present life. Love this author but this book was not a favorite.

This is the fourth Penelope Lively book I have read and my least favorite because I found the main character, Claudia repulsive as  a person and as a woman.  She's a rebeliousl, always argumentative, contrary, feeling superior always to everyone in her life, even on her death bed.  The only people she has loved in her life is her brother, Gordon and Tom, the tank commander she met in Egypt during WWII when she was a war correspondent.  She was almost likable in his company.Her attempts to write history (and the narrative goes in and out of the present) are not a chronological sequence of history but more of her opinions on historical events.  After a while, it sounds pretty self-serving and tedious.  The part of the book that is interesting, in fact, saves it is the romance with Tom, and the diary he leaves behind of his experiences at the front before he is killed.  His sister sends the diary to Claudia.  This prevents the book from becoming a total waste of time. I could hardly wait to finish it.  It's a departure for this author and I was very disappointed.

title: Moon Tiger

summary:
Penelope Lively's Booker Prize winning classic, Moon Tiger is a haunting story of loss and desire.

Claudia Hampton - beautiful, famous, independent, dying.

But she remains defiant to the last, telling her nurses that she will write a 'history of the world . . . and in the process, my own'. And it is her story from a childhood just after the First World War through the Second and beyond. 

But Claudia's life is entwined with others and she must allow those who knew her, loved her, the chance to speak, to put across their point of view. There is Gordon, brother and adversary; Jasper, her untrustworthy lover and father of Lisa, her cool conventional daughter; and then there is Tom, her one great love, found and lost in wartime Egypt.

'Leaves its traces in the air long after you've put it away' Anne Tyler
story_arc:
Bad luck, followed by promise, ending in a
                    final fall
